__data__.text: The region of central southern Turkey and northwestern Syria is defined by the convergence of the African, Arabian, and Anatolian tectonic plates. The Dead Sea Transform (DST) marks the boundary between the African and Arabian plates, allowing for the northward movement of Arabia concerning Africa. The DST connects to the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) at the Marash Triple Junction, which represents the boundary between the Arabian and Anatolian plates. The EAF extends westward, linking to the Cyprus arc via the Latakia Ridge, and is divided into seven segments, including Karlıova, Ilıca, Palu, Pütürge, Erkenek, Pazarcık, and Amanos. The EAF accommodates the westward movement of the Anatolian Plate, which is being pushed in that direction by the northward movement of the Arabian Plate.

The Amanos segment of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) is sometimes viewed as part of the Dead Sea Transform (DST) or a transitional structure between the EAF and DST. A northern strand of the EAF has been identified, consisting of several segments, including Sürgü, Çardak, Savrun, Çokak, Toprakkale, Yumurtalık, Karataş, Yakapınar, and Düziçi–İskenderun. The slip rate along the EAF system's main strand decreases from the Karlıova segment to the Amanos segment, while the Çardak segment on the northern strand has a slip rate of 2.5 mm per year. The Sürgü-Çardak Fault is a notable feature, running north of the EAF, extending east-west for 160 km.

The Sürgü-Çardak Fault is an east-west striking, 160 km long fault located north of the EAF, consisting of two segments - Sürgü (70 km) and Çardak (90 km). Seismic activity on this fault is low, with only one recorded M 6.8 earthquake in 1544. The northernmost part of the DST is divided into seven segments, according to the 2013 "Active Fault Map of Turkey," but there is some disagreement among scientists about which faults belong to the DST and which to the EAF. These segments include Afrin, Sermada, Armanaz, Hacıpaşa, Yesemek, Sakçagöz, and Narlı.

The EAF has experienced significant seismic activity in recent centuries, with several large earthquakes occurring along various segments, such as the 1789 Palu (M 7.2), 1795 Pazarcık (M 7.0), 1866 Karlıova (M 7.2), 1872 Amanos (M 7.2), 1874 Palu (M 7.1), 1875 Palu (M 6.7), 1893 Erkenek (M 7.1), 1971 Karlıova (M 6.6), and 2020 Pütürge (Mw 6.8) events. There is a tentative association of other historical earthquakes, like the 1114 and 1513 Marash earthquakes, with the Pazarcık segment of the EAF. In the eastern region, the Palu and Pütürge segments exhibit a pattern of approximately 150-year recurrence intervals for M 6.8-7.0 earthquakes.

The Pazarcık and Amanos segments in the western part of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) have longer recurrence intervals for significant earthquakes compared to the eastern segments. Specifically, the intervals are 237-772 years for M 7.0-7.4 earthquakes in Pazarcık and 414-917 years for similar magnitudes in Amanos. A 2002 research paper identified two sections of the EAF with high seismic hazard potential, one of which was in Elazığ and Bingöl, situated between the 1874 and 1971 earthquake rupture zones. This section experienced a Mw 6.1 earthquake in 2010. The 2020 Mw 6.8 earthquake occurred in a seismic gap to the southwest, between the 1893/1905 and 1874 earthquake zones.

The 2020 Mw 6.8 earthquake occurred in a seismic gap between the 1893/1905 and 1874 earthquake zones in the western part of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF). This region, along with the Kahramanmaraş section, which last ruptured in 1513 and has a potential for M 7.3 earthquakes, have higher seismic hazard potential compared to the eastern segments. The EAF has a history of large earthquakes, with several events in the northern part resulting in significant fatalities, such as the 115, 526, 587, 1138, 1170, and 1822 earthquakes. The first and largest earthquake in the 2020 sequence was measured at Mww 7.8 by the USGS and GCMT, Mw 8.0 by GEOSCOPE, and Mw 7.7 and ML 7.4 by KOERI.

The 2020 Mw 8.0 earthquake, as reported by GEOSCOPE, and Mw 7.7, as reported by KOERI, took place in Gaziantep Province near the Turkey-Syria border, with a strike-slip fault focal mechanism. Its epicenter was located at 37.166°N 37.032°E and hypocenter at 10.0 km (USGS) and 5 km (KOERI) depths. This event is one of the strongest in Turkey's history, comparable to the 1939 Erzincan earthquake, and the largest observed on land worldwide in recent years. It followed the Mw 7.8 earthquake in the same sequence, making it the strongest pair of earthquakes recorded since August 2021. The region has a higher seismic hazard potential compared to the eastern segments of the East Anatolian Fault.

The Mw 7.5/7.6/7.7 earthquake, following the Mw 7.8 event, is the strongest pair of earthquakes since August 2021, with both being the largest and only observed on land in quick succession. Its epicenter was near Ekinözü, approximately 95 km northeast of the initial quake, and had a depth of 5-8 km. These earthquakes are now reevaluated as Mw 7.95 ± 0.013 and Mw 7.86 ± 0.012, making them the largest in Turkey in over 2,000 years, accompanied by aftershocks.

The recent earthquakes in Turkey are the largest in over 2,000 years, followed by a significant number of aftershocks. Within 24 hours of the initial Mw 7.8 quake, over 570 aftershocks were recorded, with over 30,000 reported by May 2023. Notably, a Mww 6.7 aftershock occurred just 11 minutes after the mainshock, and several other aftershocks of varying magnitudes were recorded in the following hours. These aftershocks resulted from oblique-normal faulting, with the largest one striking near Uzunbağ in Hatay Province on 20 February.

The text discusses the aftershocks resulting from the significant earthquakes in Turkey, with the largest one being a Mww 6.3 aftershock near Uzunbağ in Hatay Province on 20 February, caused by oblique-normal faulting. The first earthquake, with a magnitude of Mw 7.8, produced over 570 aftershocks within 24 hours and over 30,000 by May 2023. Similarly, the Mw 7.7 earthquake triggered its own sequence of aftershocks, including two mb 6.0 events, and thousands of aftershocks were recorded along the Çardak Fault for about 170 km (110 mi). Seismology is the field of study involved in this analysis.

The text talks about the aftershocks from the earthquakes in Turkey being studied in the field of seismology. A USGS model using seismic waves and satellite data identified three fault segments for the Mww 7.8 earthquake. These segments, which stretch for over 40 km in length and 20 km in width, are located at varying strikes and dips. The most significant slip occurred along Segment 2, beneath Sakarya in Kahramanmaraş Province, measuring 11.2 m. Thousands of aftershocks followed the earthquake, aligning with the east-west trend of the Çardak Fault for approximately 170 km.

The Mww 7.8 earthquake's mainshock resulted in a maximum slip of 11.2 m near Sakarya, in Kahramanmaraş Province's northeastern region where Segment 1 and 2 meet. Another significant slip of 4.96 m was observed further northeast along Segment 2, northwest of Adıyaman. The Mw 7.7 earthquake that followed nine hours later had three major fault segments with specific lengths, widths, strikes, and dips. The greatest displacement of 11.4 m occurred on Segment 1. The Amanos, Pazarcık, and Erkenek segments of the Eastern Anatolian Fault Zone were involved in the Mw 7.8 rupture.

The text discusses the rupture of the Eastern Anatolian Fault (EAF) due to the Mww 7.8 and 7.7 earthquakes. The Mww 7.8 earthquake had a maximum slip of 11.2 m near Sakarya, where Segments 1 and 2 meet, and another slip of 4.96 m further northeast along Segment 2. The Mww 7.7 earthquake that followed involved three major fault segments, with the greatest displacement of 11.4 m on Segment 1. The rupture extended for approximately 370 km (230 mi), with a maximum slip of 9 m along the Pazarcık segment. The northern end of the rupture was located around 20-30 km south of the 2020 Mw 6.8 earthquake, indicating a possible seismic gap in this region. The southern segment of the EAF rupture occurred near Antakya, with slip peaking at 12 m from the surface to 7 km depth during the Mww 7.7 earthquake. Slip was mostly concentrated within the Çardak Fault and was shallower, attenuating from 8-12 km depth.

The text describes the concentrated slip along the Çardak Fault during the earthquakes, being shallower and extending to different depths for each event. The Mw 6.4 aftershock that occurred in Antakya on 20 February had a smaller rupture area and peak slip compared to the previous earthquakes. The USGS fault model suggests that the M7.8 earthquake added up to 3 bars of stress near the epicenter of the M7.7 shock on the Çardak-Sürgü Fault, potentially triggering rupture if it was already close to failure.

The stress on the Hatay Fault, which caused the Mw 6.4 aftershock on 20 February, increased by 1 bar due to the 6 February earthquakes. The sequence of events began with an initial rupture at the epicenter of the M7.8 shock on the Narlı Fault, part of the Dead Sea Transform. This rupture, a Mw 7.0 earthquake, propagated northward until it reached the Pazarcık segment of the East Anatolian Fault, then continued bilaterally. The initial rupture transitioned to supershear speed after moving around 19.5 km from the epicenter along the Narlı Fault.

The stress on the Hatay Fault increased by 1 bar due to the 6 February earthquakes, leading to a Mw 6.4 aftershock on 20 February. The sequence of events started with a Mw 7.0 earthquake on the Narlı Fault, which then propagated northward and transitioned to supershear speed. The rupture continued bilaterally, reaching the Pazarcık segment of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) and extending to the Ekernek and Amanos segments. The northeastern rupture ended 55 seconds after initiation, while the southwestern rupture stopped near Antakya after around 80 seconds. A Mw 6.8 aftershock 11 minutes later may have occurred along the Sakçagöz Fault. An analysis of seismic data showed that the rupture on the EAF occurred at subshear velocity, but transient supershear rupture episodes were observed. Supershear rupture happened along the northernmost section of the Narlı Fault where it connects with the EAF and propagated northeast at supershear velocity until its termination near Malatya. The rupture towards the southwest was mainly subshear, but supershear was likely at the southern termination in Hatay due to the fault's multiple branches and kinks. The total rupture length was approximately 560 km (350 mi).

The rupture towards Hatay at the southwestern end of the East Anatolian Fault (EAF) was mainly subshear, but likely transitioned to supershear at the fault's complex branches. This supershear rupture in Hatay resulted in strong ground motion in Antakya. A second M>7 earthquake started on the distinct Çardak–Sürgü Fault Zone, which is part of the EAF's northern strand. This rupture branched out bilaterally along the Çardak segment, continuing eastwards onto the Sürgü segment, and further extending to Malatya along the Doğanşehir Fault Zone. The rupture also propagated westwards along the Çardak segment. The total rupture length was about 160 km (99 mi), with the westward-propagating rupture moving at supershear velocity and the eastward-propagating rupture moving at subshear velocity.

The rupture caused by the main earthquakes lasted for approximately 35 seconds, followed by an Mw 6.4 aftershock in Hatay on February 20, displaying normal faulting along a northeast-southwest striking fault. Two distinct surface rupture zones were identified through satellite imagery analysis and fieldwork, with the primary rupture, resulting from the first earthquake, stretching 320 km (200 mi) and the secondary rupture, from the second earthquake, measuring 150 km (93 mi). The aftershock also occurred along the Hatay Fault. The rupture behavior on the Çardak–Sürgü Fault Zone featured both supershear and subshear velocities, branching out in multiple directions.

The text describes the findings of an analysis of satellite imagery and fieldwork following earthquakes in the region of Hatay, specifically focusing on the observed surface ruptures. The primary rupture, caused by the initial earthquake, extended for 320 km (200 mi) and featured both supershear and subshear velocities. A secondary rupture, resulting from a subsequent Mw 6.4 aftershock, measured 150 km (93 mi) and also occurred along the Hatay Fault. Remote sensing and field observations revealed 30 km (19 mi) of surface rupture with a large normal faulting component, extending from north of Antakya, Hatay Province towards Pazarcık, Kahramanmaraş Province and Gölbaşı, Adıyaman Province. The surface ruptures caused damage to the westernmost part of Hatay Airport and a major canal in the Amik Valley, leading to flooding. The maximum displacement on the surface was measured at 7.3 m (24 ft), and a 15 km (9.3 mi) surface rupture with an offset of 2.5 m (8 ft 2 in) was traced south from Pazarcık.

The analysis of satellite imagery and fieldwork following earthquakes in Hatay revealed a large surface rupture extending from north of Antakya towards Pazarcık and Gölbaşı. A 15 km segment of this rupture, located south of Pazarcık, had a 2.5 m offset. Ground displacements were up to 5 m in the Golbaşı to Nurdağı area. The surface rupture's size was remarkable, comparable to the 1906 San Francisco earthquake along the San Andreas Fault. Large offsets of 6-8 m were found along the Sürgü-Çardak Fault, with the maximum offset of 8.6 m along a road near Gözpınar. Ground acceleration values in some areas near the fault rupture exceeded 1 g, and three USGS seismic installations recorded significant ground accelerations and velocities, with Hassa measuring 0.9082 g in ground acceleration and 215.34 cm/s in ground velocity. The surface ruptures caused damage to the westernmost part of Hatay Airport and a major canal in the Amik Valley, resulting in flooding.

The earthquake's impact in Hatay and Adiyaman regions was significant, with peak ground acceleration (PGA) generally exceeding 0.5g, and reaching as high as 2g in some areas. Specifically, Hassa recorded 0.9082g PGA and 215.34 cm/s in ground velocity, while the maximum PGA of 2.212g was recorded in Pazarcık Belediyesi Parkı. This extreme intensity, estimated as MMI XI-XII, caused significant damage in Pazarcık and Antakya, despite only sparse damage to a government health facility near the PGA recording station. The earthquake also caused damage to Hatay Airport and a major canal in the Amik Valley, resulting in flooding.

The earthquake's impact was extreme (MMI XI) along the fault rupture from the epicenter to Antakya, with varying degrees of intensity in surrounding regions. Areas such as Kahramanmaraş and İskenderun experienced violent to extreme shaking, while Malatya and Adıyaman had severe to violent shaking. Gaziantep, Kilis, Idlib, and Aleppo experienced very strong to severe shaking, and Adana and Şanlıurfa had strong to very strong shaking. The second earthquake had a maximum MMI of X (extreme). Geological effects included liquefaction and lateral spreading along the southern portion of the Mw 7.8 rupture on the East Anatolian Fault, particularly in the Amik Valley and Orontes River plain, north of Antakya, Hatay Province. Observations were limited in high-elevation areas due to snow cover and lack of satellite data.

The earthquakes caused widespread geological effects in the Amik Valley, Orontes River plain, and Lake Gölbaşı, with liquefaction and lateral spreading observed. High-elevation areas had limited observations due to snow cover and lack of satellite data. Specifically, Samandağ experienced liquefaction, while Lake Gölbaşı had lateral spreading and submerged parts of its shore. In İskenderun, subsidence due to lateral spreading caused significant damage, and liquefaction resulted in sand ejecta burying Atatürk Boulevard. Regular flooding in the city after the earthquakes may be attributed to liquefaction and damage to the coast and water infrastructure, with the sea inundating parts of the city and coastal areas.

The earthquakes resulted in the sea inundating up to 200 meters of İskenderun, with large waves and a tsunami contributing to the coastal flooding. A tsunami was recorded in the Mediterranean Sea, despite the epicenter being 90 km inland, with small waves observed in Famagusta, Cyprus, and the Turkish coast. Tsunami warnings were issued but later withdrawn. The disaster resulted in significant damage and casualties in Turkey, including over 50,000 deaths, 107,000 injuries, and the destruction of around 345,000 apartments, affecting millions of people and buildings.

The earthquakes caused widespread destruction, affecting over 15.73 million people and 4 million buildings, with more than 2 million residents evacuated to other provinces. The disaster significantly impacted Turkey's agriculture production, with the UN reporting heavy damage to crops, livestock, and rural infrastructure. Over 500 university buildings were affected, and 1.25 million buildings were inspected, revealing 164,000 were destroyed or severely damaged. The International Organization for Migration estimated over 2.7 million people lost their homes. The Turkish government's damage assessment indicated that at least 61,722 buildings needed to be demolished, with a high concentration in certain provinces.

The earthquakes resulted in significant damage to infrastructure, including roads with large cracks and the collapse of numerous buildings in cities like Adana and Malatya. A substantial number of buildings were destroyed or needed demolition in both provinces. Many mosques, including a historic one, and other structures in Malatya were damaged or destroyed. Casualties occurred when apartments and hotels collapsed, and at Malatya Erhaç Airport, where part of the ceiling fell in. In Akçadağ, 11 people lost their lives due to the earthquakes. Recovery efforts uncovered body parts in the rubble. The disaster had a severe impact on both urban and rural areas, causing extensive damage to buildings, agriculture, and displacing millions of people.

The earthquakes caused extensive damage to various areas, including the Arslantepe Mound in Akçadağ where 11 lives were lost, 263 deaths in Doğanşehir, and significant damage in Gaziantep. Historical sites such as Gaziantep Castle, Şirvani Mosque, and Liberation Mosque were severely affected in Gaziantep. A large number of buildings collapsed in the city center and Nizip, resulting in numerous fatalities. Nurdağı had high death toll and extensive destruction of houses. Mass graves were created to handle the high number of fatalities. Gaziantep Oğuzeli Airport limited its service to rescue flights only. Sakçagözü suffered heavily with 90% of houses destroyed and 256 deaths reported. Overall, the disaster caused significant loss of life, destruction of buildings, and displacement of people in urban and rural areas.

The earthquakes led to the suspension of regular flights at Gaziantep Oğuzeli Airport, allowing only rescue flights. Sakçagözü experienced extensive damage with 90% of houses destroyed and many fatalities. İslahiye had a high death toll, numerous injuries, and significant destruction of apartments. Several districts in Hatay Province suffered heavily, with thousands of buildings collapsing, requiring demolition, or severely damaged. Antakya was particularly affected, with a majority of homes and buildings destroyed or damaged, and a large number of deaths. The disaster also caused the collapse of a luxury apartment in Hatay, trapping and killing hundreds of residents. Hatay Airport's runway was damaged, resulting in flight cancellations.

The luxury Rönesans Rezidans apartment collapsed, trapping around 800 people and killing approximately 750 residents. Both provincial hospitals and a police station were destroyed, along with the building of Hatay State's assembly. Notable damage occurred at St. Paul's Church, Hatay Archaeology Museum, Antakya Synagogue, and Habib'i Neccar Mosque. A gas pipeline exploded, and many buildings in Güzelburç district and nearly all houses in central and Cebrail districts collapsed. The local football club Hatayspor's headquarters in Antakya suffered severe damage, resulting in the death of some team members. In Kırıkhan District, over 1,800 buildings collapsed, and around 7,000 others were significantly damaged or needed demolition. Hatay Airport's runway was severely damaged, but repairs were completed by Ankara Metropolitan Municipality on 12 February, enabling its reopening.

In Kırıkhan District, a significant number of buildings collapsed, and many others were severely damaged or required demolition. Similarly, substantial damage occurred in Defne, Reyhanlı, Arsuz, Kumlu, and Payas, with numerous buildings destroyed and many more badly damaged or slated for demolition. In İskenderun, a large fire broke out at the port on February 6, caused by a flammable oil-carrying container, resulting in the port's closure and diversion of ships. The fire was put out multiple times but reignited until it was finally extinguished on February 10.

The fire at İskenderun's port, started by an oil-carrying container, proved challenging to extinguish, reigniting twice before being put out on the fourth day. This incident led to the destruction of 3,670 containers and a three-month suspension of port operations. In the city, 534 buildings were leveled, 337 more needed demolition, and 4,622 were severely damaged. Flooding also affected the city's shoreline. Meanwhile, Erzin District experienced significant damage to 31 buildings and the demolition of 897 others, but its largest town, Erzin, escaped major destruction due to strict building codes. Consequently, around 20,000 displaced individuals sought refuge in Erzin, causing a 50% increase in the town's population. The Cathedral of the Annunciation suffered almost complete devastation, and the disaster resulted in over 3,109 fatalities and more than 12,000 injuries in İskenderun.

The disaster caused significant destruction in various districts, with Erzin being a refuge for 20,000 displaced individuals, doubling its population. Samandağ had 670 building collapses, 9,212 damaged, and over 7,850 fatalities. Hassa District, Altınözü, Yayladağı, and Belen also suffered extensive building damage and losses. Dörtyol lost 115 buildings and faced extensive damage to 2,030 others. Kahramanmaraş conducted mass burials for over 5,000 bodies, aiming to accommodate 10,000 in total, while approximately 75% of the city's buildings were damaged or destroyed. Strict building codes helped protect Erzin's largest town from major destruction.

The disaster led to extensive damage and loss in several districts, including Elbistan with 924 fatalities and 1,825 injuries, and over 2,000 buildings destroyed. Ordekdede village suffered near-total destruction of single-story buildings, with 34 deaths. Ekinözü had 11 deaths, 107 destroyed houses, and 70% building damage. Afşin reported at least 180 deaths, significant building destruction, and damage to the Afşin-Elbistan Thermal Power Plant. Ericek village in Göksun saw 95% of homes affected and 152 deaths, while Nurhak had around 200 deaths and severe damage to all houses. Strict building codes helped protect Erzin's largest town from major destruction. The city official's plan is to accommodate 10,000 bodies in mass graves, as approximately 75% of the city's buildings were damaged or destroyed.

The disaster caused significant damage in various areas, such as Ericek village in Göksun with 95% of homes affected and 152 fatalities, and Nurhak having approximately 200 deaths and severe damage to all houses. In Türkoğlu, 1,171 buildings collapsed while 4,500 more needed demolition. Adıyaman Province suffered extensive destruction, with over 20,000 buildings and 56,600 apartments destroyed, including four neighborhoods in the city of Adıyaman and many buildings along Atatürk Boulevard. Several historical sites, like the city hall, a 6th-century mosque, and Gölbaşı District's state hospital, were destroyed. In Harmanlı village, 80-90% of the area was destroyed. Multiple neighborhoods and districts across the affected provinces experienced substantial damage.

The second earthquake led to further destruction in the affected areas. Harmanlı village in Gölbaşı District suffered extensive damage, with 80-90% of it destroyed. In Gölbaşı, 71% of the infrastructure was damaged or destroyed, resulting in 695 fatalities and over 400 injuries. Besni District had 410 deaths, mostly in the town itself. Kâhta reported at least 55 fatalities. Diyarbakir Province saw 8,086 buildings damaged, demolished, or destroyed, including the UNESCO World Heritage Site, Diyarbakır Fortress, and the adjacent Hevsel Gardens. The Galeria complex in Yenişehir, Şanlıurfa Province, collapsed, killing 89 and injuring 22. Additionally, 466 buildings in Şanlıurfa Province were heavily damaged, with 201 destroyed, and structures around the Pool of Abraham were affected.

The second earthquake caused additional destruction in the affected areas, resulting in further damage to structures around the Pool of Abraham and the partial collapse of the minaret at a religious shrine, contaminating the water. The Eyüp Prophet Mosque's minaret was also damaged in Eyyübiye District. The Osman Ağan Apartment collapsed, killing 33 people. In Osmaniye Province, 1,739 buildings were heavily damaged or destroyed, and in Merkez District, at least 1,088 buildings were destroyed or needed urgent demolition. Kilis Province had 119 buildings destroyed and 138 heavily damaged, while Batman Province had 218 buildings damaged and 15 completely destroyed. Mardin Province experienced damage to 249 buildings and a heart attack-related death in Kızıltepe District. Bingöl Province saw some houses cracked and livestock killed, and Samsun's stadium was damaged.

The second earthquake led to further destruction, including damaged houses and livestock loss in Bingöl Province, stadium damage in Samsun, building collapses and damage in Kayseri, Muş, and Sivas Provinces, and a barn collapse in Muş. Notably, several individuals passed away, such as a member of the Grand National Assembly of Turkey, a soccer goalkeeper, a former national handball player and his son, a community leader, and three soldiers during rescue efforts.

The second earthquake resulted in significant damage in several Turkish provinces, leading to fatalities such as a member of the Turkish parliament, a soccer goalkeeper, a former national handball player and his son, a community leader, and three soldiers. In addition, 26 local journalists, four doctors, 120 police officers, and 32 gendarmeries were among the Turkish casualties. In Syria, at least 8,476 people died, including 2,153 children and 1,524 women, with many more injured. The Syrian Ministry of Health reported over 2,248 deaths and 2,950 injuries in government-held areas, while in rebel-held territories, at least 4,547 people died and 2,200 were injured. The Syrian Network for Human Rights and the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights noted that the death toll might be higher due to unregistered burials and hospital deaths.

The Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported unregistered burials and hospital deaths, with the total number of fatalities potentially being higher than reported. Syria's National Earthquake Centre described the earthquake as the largest in its history. An estimated 5.37 million people in Syria have been displaced, and 10.9 million have been affected. Over 123 residential areas were severely damaged, with at least 453 schools and 10,600 buildings collapsing or sustaining damage. Hundreds were killed in Jindires, Atarib, and Jableh, where many buildings also collapsed. Power plants, water facilities, hospitals, and public infrastructure were damaged as well.

On February 10, four bodies were recovered and 15 more were being extracted from debris, while six more were found in Latakia Governorate on February 11. Many civilians were trapped under rubble for hours in several villages due to insufficient rescue teams. The region experienced significant building damage, including at Tishreen University and an eight-story building in Hama, resulting in numerous fatalities. The Afrin Dam reportedly cracked and burst, causing flooding in Al-Tloul village, worsened by heavy rains.

The Afrin Dam failed on February 9, causing severe flooding in Al-Tloul village, which was worsened by heavy rains. This led to the displacement of around 500 families, and reportedly, 35-40 people died in the village. Several buildings were damaged or destroyed. In Atarib, 148 bodies were taken to an underground hospital, with some of them missing body parts. Various archaeological sites in Tartus Governorate suffered damage, and Idlib Governorate's hospital received 30 bodies. The village of Azmarin, Idlib Governorate, experienced a significant loss with at least 260 fatalities, 300 injuries, and 100 rescues. Emergency rooms were overwhelmed with injured individuals.

The text discusses the aftermath of the Afrin Dam failure and the earthquake in various locations in Syria. In Azmarin, Idlib Governorate, there were significant losses with over 260 fatalities, including 51 members of one family, at least 300 injuries, and 100 rescues. The earthquake also caused damage to buildings and housing in the village. In Aleppo, dozens of buildings collapsed, leading to over 444 deaths, including 163 children, and affecting around 20,000 homes, leaving 70,000 homeless. Archeological sites and the outer façade of the Aleppo National Museum were also damaged. The earthquake struck when rebel-held areas were preparing for a blizzard and dealing with a cholera outbreak. In Atarib, Aleppo, the Syrian American Medical Society hospital recovered 120 bodies.

The Syrian American Medical Society hospital in Atarib, Aleppo, recovered 120 bodies, with around 20,000 homes affected in Aleppo, leaving 70,000 homeless. The earthquake further damaged buildings and historical sites in various locations, including the prison in Rajo, where 20 prisoners believed to be ISIS members escaped, and several castles and mosques, such as Margat, Krak des Chevaliers, the Citadel of Aleppo, Sahyun Castle, and the Grand Mosque in Kobanî. Many people in Damascus fled their homes due to building cracks, with the city having already been impacted by a long-lasting civil war.

The earthquake caused further destruction in Syria, including damage to Sahyun Castle's towers and the minaret of the Grand Mosque in Kobanî. Jindires suffered significant losses, with over 1,100 people killed and 250 buildings destroyed. In Turkey, at least 6,600 Syrian residents were killed, and thousands of Syrian victims were buried due to transportation difficulties. Additionally, some Iraqi war refugees and Afghans who fled the Taliban also lost their lives in Turkey, as well as an entire Lebanese family.

The earthquake resulted in fatalities in Lebanon, with a whole family of three in Malatya and residents of Beirut passing away. Many buildings in Lebanon were damaged, and people had to leave their homes for safety. In Israel, a building was evacuated in Ashdod, and the Champion Motors Tower in Bnei Brak was slightly damaged. Nicosia, Cyprus, also experienced building damage due to the earthquake. Additionally, in Turkey, ten Azerbaijanis, an Italian family of six, an entrepreneur, nineteen students, two teachers, and a parent from Northern Cyprus, and seven other Turkish Cypriots lost their lives.

The earthquake caused fatalities in several countries, including a family in Malatya, Lebanon, and numerous individuals in Turkey, such as Azerbaijanis, an Italian family, an entrepreneur, students, teachers, and Turkish Cypriots. In Nicosia, Cyprus, building damage occurred, and six Cuvier's beaked whales were found dead, possibly due to the earthquake's impact on their echolocation system. In Iraq, houses and buildings, including Erbil's citadel, were damaged, and Egypt experienced strong tremors, with a significant crack appearing in Alexandria's Corniche. Aftershocks followed, leading to further building collapses and fatalities in Antakya, Defne, and Samandağ.

The earthquake resulted in additional fatalities in Antakya, Defne, and Samandağ, with numerous injuries reported in the region. Authorities warned of a potential tsunami and advised people to avoid the coast. In Syria, several people died due to stampedes and building collapses, while injured individuals were reported in Aleppo, Idlib, and Jinderis. Aftershocks, including a Mww 5.2 tremor near Yeşilyurt, further damaged buildings and caused casualties in Yeşilyurt. The earthquake's impact was also felt in Lebanon, Egypt, and Jordan.

The earthquake caused around 30 buildings to collapse in a town, resulting in two deaths and 140 injuries, with 12 people in serious condition. A factory collapse in Kahramanmaraş Province added one fatality and four injuries. The USGS PAGER service estimated a significant probability of extensive economic losses and a high death toll, while Risklayer predicted a potential death toll ranging from 23,284 to 105,671. Aftershocks further damaged buildings and caused additional casualties.

The earthquake's aftermath is dire, with a significant number of people potentially trapped under debris, according to a geophysics professor. The UN expects the death toll to surpass 56,000, and the WHO estimates that up to 26 million may be affected, with millions in Turkey and Syria. The earthquake has had a substantial impact on Turkey's economy, causing the lira to plummet and the stock market to experience significant losses before recovering and ultimately closing for five days.

The earthquake's financial impact on Turkey is severe, causing the stock market to plummet by 8.6% on February 7 and a further decline of over 7% on February 8 before its closure for five days. The damage cost is estimated to be around $84.1 billion USD, with $70.75 billion required for rebuilding and an additional $13.31 billion loss in national income and workforce. The Turkish government's preliminary report estimates the damage cost to be $103.6 billion, equivalent to 9% of its GDP in 2023. Meanwhile, the United Nations Development Programme estimates that between 116 million and 210 million tons of debris need to be cleared in Turkey.

The text discusses the extensive damage and financial impact of the earthquake in both Turkey and Syria. In Turkey, about half of the residential properties in the affected area are insured through Compulsory Earthquake Insurance. The United Nations Development Programme estimates that over 100 million cubic meters of debris need to be cleared, which is significantly more than any recent natural disaster. The Turkish government's preliminary report estimates the damage cost to be 9% of the country's GDP in 2023, while the UN estimated the cost to be around $84.1 billion USD.

In the aftermath, many people were trapped under rubble in both countries.

In the aftermath of the earthquake in Turkey, thousands of people were trapped under rubble and many were missing. Social media was used by survivors to share their locations and by those who lost contact with relatives to send pleas for help. Many people were left homeless and sought shelter in mosques, hotels, shopping malls, stadiums, and community centers. Authorities faced criticism for insufficient search and rescue efforts, particularly in Hatay Province, where the airport's damaged runway complicated rescue operations. Officials reported rescuing over 1,800 people in the province by February 7. In Malatya Province, nearly 250,000 displaced persons took shelter in schools.

After the earthquake in Turkey, people in Gaziantep found shelter in shopping malls, stadiums, community centers, and mosques. In Malatya Province, around 250,000 displaced individuals were housed in schools, with aid from local vocational schools. Turkish humanitarian organizations, including Ahbap from Haluk Levent, the Turkish Philanthropy Funds, and the Turkish Red Crescent, initiated emergency appeals for assistance. Turkish Airlines offered free flights for volunteers from several provinces, and the Disaster and Emergency Management Authority called for civilian volunteers. A large number of volunteers were transported by Turkish Airlines to aid in the affected regions.

In the aftermath of the earthquake in Turkey, Turkish Airlines and Pegasus Airlines provided transportation for thousands of volunteers and evacuees to the affected regions. Specifically, Turkish Airlines transported 11,780 volunteers on 80 flights and evacuated 139,438 people on 790 flights, as well as carrying 7,833 members of search and rescue teams on 1,595 flights. Meanwhile, Pegasus Airlines evacuated 30,771 people on 169 flights. As the rescue operation was underway, search and rescue teams were promptly dispatched to the affected area, and authorities urged people to avoid entering damaged buildings.

After the earthquake in Turkey, the Turkish government, including President Erdoğan and Interior Minister Soylu, promptly dispatched search and rescue teams to the affected area and urged people to avoid entering damaged buildings. A state of emergency was declared in the 10 most affected provinces, and a level four alert was issued to request international aid. The Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency reported that 25,000 search and rescue personnel were deployed, and at least 70 countries offered assistance. Emergency services were activated, and more than 8,000 people were rescued by February 8. Additionally, Turkish Airlines and Pegasus Airlines transported thousands of volunteers, evacuees, and search and rescue teams. An "air aid corridor" was also established by the Turkish Armed Forces to facilitate search and rescue operations.

Following the earthquake in Turkey, around 380,000 people sought refuge in relief shelters or hotels. The Turkish Armed Forces established an "air aid corridor" to transport search and rescue teams, vehicles, food, blankets, and psychological support. Turkey requested assistance from NATO and allies, while over 53,000 emergency workers, including a team of 90 miners from Soma, were deployed. Adverse weather conditions and damaged roads hampered rescue efforts. President Erdoğan visited affected areas, acknowledging response shortcomings but denying insufficient personnel.

After the earthquake in Turkey, President Erdoğan admitted to response deficiencies but disputed claims of insufficient rescue personnel, labeling some critics as "provocateurs." AFAD announced on February 19 that search and rescue operations would mostly end in the affected provinces, with focus on 40 buildings in Kahramanmaraş and Hatay. The "Omuz Omuza" campaign, organized by the Ministry of Youth and Sports, Turkish Football Federation, Super League Clubs Association Foundation and beIN Media Group, raised over $44.8 million in its first day. The government announced it would provide compensation to those who lost their homes due to the disaster.

After the earthquake in Turkey, the government announced it would provide compensation to those who lost their homes, with ₺15,000 in relocation assistance per household for moderate to total destruction, and rent assistance of up to ₺5,000 for homeowners and ₺2,000 for tenants. The president promised to rebuild destroyed homes within a year and provide temporary accommodation. Additionally, tax obligations in the affected region were postponed until 31 July 2023. The government also committed to subsidizing rents for those who prefer not to stay in tents.

Post-earthquake efforts in Turkey involve over 141,000 rescue personnel, including international teams, working in the 10 affected provinces. The government allocated 100 billion lira for disaster response and plans to build 270,000 homes in the affected provinces and villages. Over 1.9 million people have been provided with temporary accommodations, such as dormitories, tents, hotels, and containers. Around 1.6 million people have access to shelter, with 890,000 in dormitories and 50,000 in hotels. In Gaziantep, construction has started on 105,000 new homes, with more than half already completed. The Şırnak district is set to be demolished and reconstructed.

The government is constructing a total of 650,000 homes, with 319,000 of them expected to be completed by the end of 2023. Additional facilities such as schools, hospitals, bazaars, markets, and green spaces are also being developed. Meanwhile, tensions persist as Turkey accuses the People's Defense Units of conducting an MRL attack, resulting in Turkish army retaliation. Unfortunately, on February 9, a prison riot in Hatay led to the death of three inmates and the injury of 12 more due to soldiers' gunfire.

The Israeli search-and-rescue group, United Hatzalah, left Turkey due to a specific and immediate threat.
